How to use Gmail as a desktop application
03 Nov 2019, 07:00 by Artyom Kozoriz
Run the client in a separate window, work offline and use other tricks to interact with letters faster.
1. Add a shortcut to run



To open Gmail as a regular application, create a shortcut and place it on your desktop, taskbar or dock. Here's how to do it:

Open Gmail in Chrome.
Go to ‚ÄúMenu‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúAdvanced Tools‚Äù and select ‚ÄúCreate Shortcut‚Äù.
Check the box ‚ÄúOpen in a separate window‚Äù and click the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button.
On Windows, the shortcut will appear on the desktop, on macOS, on Launchpad.

2. Turn on offline mode



Since Gmail is now an application, not an online service, it should work even without the Internet. To do this, enable offline mode.

Open the ‚ÄúInbox‚Äù folder, click on the gear icon and select ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù.
Go to the ‚ÄúOffline‚Äù tab and check the box ‚ÄúEnable offline mail access‚Äù.
Click "Save Changes" at the bottom of the page.

3. Set Gmail as the primary client
So that when processing mail links the system does not transfer to the standard client, you need to set Gmail as the default mail application. On Windows and macOS, this is done differently.
Windows




Launch the Start menu and click the gear icon.
Go to ‚ÄúApplications‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúDefault Applications‚Äù.
Select Google Chrome as your main email program.

macOS




Open the Mail app.
Go to "Settings" ‚Üí "General".
From the "Mail Client" drop-down list, select Gmail.app.

4. Turn on notifications



Without notifications of new letters, the email client will not be complete. Gmail supports this feature and can display notifications on the desktop, like all applications. It is configured as follows.

Open Inbox, click the gear icon and select ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù.
On the "General" tab, go to the "Notifications on the desktop" section and check "Enable notifications about new letters."
Click the ‚ÄúSave Changes‚Äù button at the bottom of the page.

5. Use hotkeys



Shortcuts are great at speeding things up, allowing you to quickly pick up blockages of mail and respond to letters. Like the online version of Gmail, the desktop application supports hot keys. All you need to do is enable the function in the settings.

On the ‚ÄúInbox‚Äù screen, click on the gear icon and open ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù.
Go to the "General" tab and find the "Shortcut keys" section.
Check the "Enable" item and click "Save Changes" at the very bottom of the page.
